DeregistrationReasonOtherText: SEUSA has purchased the CRC facility

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RMP Executive Summary 2004

Colorado Refining Company (CRC) is a crude oil refinery regulated as a program level 3 facility under the EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) regulations.  CRC protects its employees, the public and the environment, from exposure to toxic and hazardous chemicals used in the production of petroleum fuels.  In order to maintain safe operations CRC has extensive environmental, health and safety procedures and programs designed to minimize the possibility of an accidental release.  

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

CRC is strongly committed to protect, its employee, public and the environment from accidental releases.  Our comprehensive accidental release prevention program uses both management and engineering controls to eliminate of reduce the risk of accidental release. Management controls are work procedures, safety policies, rules, supervision, and training implemented with the goal of reducing the possibility of an accidental release.  Engineering controls eliminate or reduce the possibility of an accidental release through the use or substitution of engineered machinery or equipment.  The Refinery has the following management and engineering controls in place to minimize the possibility of an accidental release. 

Management Controls

?    Employee Training and Certification for Compliance with Environmental, Safety, and Operations Regulations and Requirements 
?    Emergency Response, Public Notification, and First Aid Training
?    Contractor Training and Certification
?    Audits of Programs and Procedures to Prevent Releases of Hazardous Materials
   o    Hazards Analyses of Process Equipment and Facilities
   o    Standard and Emergency Operating Procedures
   o    Operator Training Programs
   o    Maintenance Procedures
?    Investment in Environmental Control and Safety Equipment and Systems
   o    Process Controls to Ensure Proper Equipment Operation
   o    Emergency Response Equipment to Control Fires and Emissions of Hazardous

Materials
   o    Emissions Monitoring Equipment

Engineering Controls

?    Equipment Design by Qualified Engineers and Contractors
?    Process Hazards Analyses to Detect and Correct Equipment Design and Operating Deficiencies
?    Analysis of Processes to Determine Safe Operating Limits and Eliminate Unsafe Operating Conditions
?    Inspection of Equipment and Processes to Find and Correct Deficiencies
?    Formal Review of Equipment, Materials, and Process Operation Changes to Verify Safe Design and Operation

The facility Emergency Response plan is designed to minimize hazards to human health, property and the environment from fires, explosions, or any unplanned sudden on non-sudden release of hazardous waste or hazardous constituents at the Refinery.   In the event of an accidental release the Refinery has programs and procedures to respond to a release, investigate the cause and take corrective actions.  

The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled

The CRC facility has seven (7) stationary source processes that contain seventeen (17) RMP regulated substances; three (3) toxic regulated substances and fourteen (14) flammable regulated substances.  The majority of the RMP regulated flammable substances are part of a flammable mixture contained in the processes equipment or storage vessels as part of the production of petroleum products such as gasoline.  In the past 5 years there have been minor changes to the refinery process equipment.  None of these process changes effected the RMP regulatory classification of a process or added any additional RMP substances at the site.

Toxic Materials at Colorado Refining Company

The Refinery stores three (3) potentially toxic chemicals at its facility: ammonia, chlorine and hydrogen sulfide.  None of the toxic materials is in a quantity sufficient to be considered by OSHA and EPA as a concern to the public from an accidental release.  CRC does not store any RMP regulated toxic substances onsite above the threshold value.

Flammable Materials at Colorado Refining Company

The Refinery processes flammable materials as a matter of course.  However, most equipment does not contain flammable material sufficient to pose a hazard to the public. The Refinery has fourteen (14) flammable materials in excess of RMP reporting thresholds: Butane, Butene, Ethane, Ethylene, Hydrogen, Isobutane, Isopentane, Methane, Pentane, Propane, Propylene, 1-Pentene, 2 pentene (E) and 2 Pentene (Z).  All fourteen (14) flammable materials are liquids in pressure storage, but will evaporate into the atmosphere in the event of a leak presenting possible fire and explosion hazards.  None of these compounds are toxic, but all can cause asphyxiation from oxygen displacement. Of these, isobutane has the greatest potential for offsite effects in the event of an accidental release.  Isobutane is stored in 1240 barrel pressure storage vessels onsite.

General Prevention Programs 

CRC?s Commerce City facility was designed and constructed in accordance with NFPA-58 Standard, 1967 Edition.  The Refinery is in compliance with both the EPA RMP (40 CFR part 68)A and OSHA Process Management Safety (PSM) (29 CFR 1910.119) prevention programs.  Continuing compliance is assured through regular reviews and updates of each program.  The following is a brief description of the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at the stationary source.

Process Safety Information
The Refinery maintains a detailed record of safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all processes.

Process Hazard Analysis
The Refinery conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with our processes are identified and controlled efficiently.  The methodology used to carry out these analyses is Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP).  The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and a

re revalidated at a regular interval of (time period).  Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.

Operating Procedures
The Refinery maintains written operating procedures.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround.  The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.

Training
The Refinery has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes.  Refresher training is provided at least every three years and more frequently as needed.

Accident History 

In the past 5 years CRC has had no RMP accidental releases of RMP chemicals stored on-site above the threshold quantity from a covered process unit as defined by 40 CFR part 68.42(a).  

Emergency Response Program

In the event of a release, CRC has an Emergency Response Team that is trained to respond to chemical emergencies, fires and medical emergencies. As part of the Emergency Response Plan CRC has mutual aid training for our responders with our neighboring facilities and with the South Adams County Volunteer Fire Department.  Both the Refinery and the South Adams County Volunteer Fire Department develop plans for a public response to such an emergency.  Emergency responses include public emergency notification, public evacuation or sequestration, as appropriate, and training of local police, fire, medical, and other emergency officials in handling, with trained Refinery personnel, a significant public emergency.  The Refinery also trains and equips its personnel to handle leaks and fires that can affect employees and the public. Refinery personnel are considered the most important element in controlling and mitigating the effects of a process rel

ease. The Refinery responders attend training at the University of Nevada, Reno and are certified with the Division of Fire Safety in Colorado.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The Refinery has not had a RMP accidental release during the last 5 years.  Further, in the past 5 years there have been no changes to the facility processes that effect the RMP regulated chemical storage or new RMP chemicals held onsite above the threshold value.  The refinery will continue with its current programs and procedures to minimize the possibility of and accidental release to the environment.
